nodes.bodyText: Why break here? Is it supposed to process next element in List ?

The condition of the upper loop (that reads the data) is: iterator.hasNext() && output.size() <= TARGET_SIZE && rowCount <= MAX_ROWS_PER_PAGE meaning "keep reading data until the iterator is not empty and the threshold per page is not crossed". If the upper loop finishes it means either of two conditions:

The current iterator has no more data
The buffer is full

For the first condition we transition to the second iterator. And while we do that - we log statistics for the first (there's 1 iterator per input fragment).
For the second condition we need to end the loop, as we've read the whole page.
Initialize to 0?

That's what I had initially. But if the elapsed time is below 1s the output will contain weird 0rows/s that is confusing. It is better to display <total_rows>rows/s in this case that I find less confusing.
just like long averageRowSize = 0
ditto
nit. %s rows/s Missing space?
This is same as 60.55kB/s. We print it without a space. Same for rows/s -> 2000rows/s
I would prefer just operation.toString()
No worry, spark accumulator will list all taskIds up to thousands, it is better to keep it short.
curious why 20_000 will be better than 10_000 ? ;)

I'm going to use if for both now, zero columns an non zero columns pages. 20_000 seem to be better (e.g.: for a single bigint column page the size will be ~160kb instead of 80kb). We usually try to keep the page size above 100kb.

Note this means when one remote source is consumed, we will return (instead of try to fill TARGET_SIZE or MAX_ROWS_PER_PAGE). Curious if there is any reason for this? :)
(the code has the same semantic than before)

I see,  it will be easier to understand using
if (output.size() > TARGET_SIZE || rowCount > MAX_ROWS_PER_PAGE) { break;} else { // stats update }

Explained it here:
#14938 (comment)

I see, it will be easier to understand using

If feels like this is about the same. In the first place we check if the iterator is done, so we need to start a new one. In the second we check if the buffer is full. I would prefer to keep it the current way.
What about name the class name as ShuffleStats?
Curious why return buffer.remaining() (as compared with buffer.size()?  Will buffer.remaining() change during object lifetime? Maybe add a comment ?
Yes. Basically we change the pointers as we advance the iterator, but we don't change the buffer itself. The entire buffer contains many rows (~1mb).
for "%sM", how many digits will be there ? What about something like "%.1fM:%.1MB" (or %.2M..)
This is just for megabytes. It is not a special formatting marker.
so essentially we will also aggregate over all the shuffle stats on driver and print it out :). Do we need to display ShuffleStats on Spark Web UI as well?
I thought it might be convenient if we want to figure out what were the shuffle speed of some particular task.
Another way to do this is to make statsMap a TreeMap so the result can be traversed in a ordered way 😄 . You can keep the current way.
Yeah, the code with TreeMap is much simpler =) My bad =)

what about just do something like
rowsPerSecond = (long) (totalProcessedRows * 1000.0 / totalElapsedWallTimeMills)
bytesPerSecond = ...

?

That's just a matter of taste I believe.
Personally I find messages like these confusing:
Total rows 1, rows per second: 1_000_000.
I would rather prefer to see something like Total rows 1, rows per second: 1 (although this isn't very mathematically correct).
What do you think?

hmmm.. if it's just for logging purpose, it can be double right? (instead of long) , so we don't need to worry about whether totalElapsedWallTimeSeconds becomes 0 when the total time is less than 1 second.
Then we might either end up with NaN or 1_000_000+++ rows/second that I personally find a little confusing. But I don't have a strong opinion here.
